description:
Variation of the wording of condition 19 (temporary sales office) and condition 21 (A1 / D1 use: proportional split) of outline planning permission P102032 dated 08/03/11 for the: ‘Outline planning application showing 'layout', 'scale' and 'access' for the phased demolition and phased redevelopment of the Packington Estate allowing for the erection of part 1 to 8 storey buildings (some with basement level) to provide for 394 affordable dwellings comprising: 168x1; 111x2; 64x3; 34x4; 15x5 and 3x6 bedroom flats/maisonettes/houses (1315 habitable rooms), 301 market dwellings comprising: 170x1 and 125x2 bedroom flats /maisonettes and 6 x studio apartments (722 habitable rooms), 750sqm of shop and non-residential institution floorspace (A1 and D1 use), 290sqm community centre (D1 use) and an outdoor recreation facility of no less than 446sqm. Creation of  open space (hard and soft landscaped and play areas) of no less than 6,783sqm, semi-private open space of no less than 265sqm and private gardens of no less than 10,956sqm, new roads and a cycle path, no more than 238 car parking spaces and no less than 590 bicycle spaces’.  The variation would secure the following changes:
A]	Reduction of the size of shop and non-residential institution floorspace (A1/D1 use) from 750sqm to 702sqm (GEA)
B]	Clarification of the amount of community centre (D1 use) floorspace provided, being for 290 (NIA) and 324sqm (GEA)
decision_conditions:
The application for the approval of reserved matters must be made to the Local Planning Authority no later than 06 February 2012, being the expiry date of the original outline planning consent (LBI ref: P081704) and the development to which the permission relates must be begun no later than the expiration of two (2) years from the final approval of the reserved matters, or in the case of approval on different dates, the final approval of the last such matter approved. 

REASON: To comply with Section 92(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 as amended by Section 51(2) of the Planning Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.
